description: Derivatives of the word "evangel" or "evangelical" that pertain to Christian evangelism or the spread of the gospel, often in relation to its influence, practice, or criticism.
Words conveying intense emotions or desires, often with a focus on lust or extreme attraction, and phrases with "Luke", which typically refers to a biblical passage or the Gospel of Luke.
The term "evangel" often appearing in words related to Christianity and Protestantism, signifying the act of spreading the gospel or a Christian denomination.

Christian-related nouns, particularly those referring to religious texts or concepts, such as "Gospel", "Evangelistic", "Sermon", "Apostolic", and "Dharma", often used in formal or informative contexts.

A specific noun often denoting a concept, idea, or system in a religious or philosophical context, such as "Gospel", "Dharma", "Gossip", "News", "Evangelical", "Kingdom", and "Catechism", with the word itself being more relevant to the context than its surrounding tokens.
A book in the Bible, typically the Gospel of Luke, often referenced with a chapter and verse number.
References to the Gospel of Luke, often including the book name "Luke" and a chapter or verse number, usually in the format "Luke X:Y".
References to the Gospel of Matthew, a New Testament book in the Bible.
References to specific biblical books or chapters, particularly the Gospel of Matthew, along with chapter and verse numbers, often denoted by abbreviations such as "Mt", "Mat", or "Matt".
References to religious texts or terminology, primarily Christian and Buddhist, including gospels, psalms, and sermons, often signifying sacred or inspirational writings.
References to Christian texts, especially the Gospels, as well as other Christian-related terms, and also mentions of gossip, news, and other non-Christian terms.
The term "gospel" in a context of Christian scripture or teachings.
The term "evangel" or its variations, often associated with Christianity and referring to the spreading or promotion of a particular set of beliefs, especially those related to the Christian gospel.
Book titles or names, specifically referencing the Gospel of Matthew in the Bible.
References to the Gospel of Matthew, often including the book name "Matthew" accompanied by a chapter and/or verse number, and sometimes abbreviated as "Mt" or "Matt".
A proper noun, specifically the word "Gospel" or its plural form "Gospels", indicating a connection to Christian scripture or values.
References to the Gospel of Luke, often including the chapter and verse number, in biblical or theological contexts.

Proper nouns, particularly those referring to important documents, religious texts, and institutions (e.g., Bible, Constitution, Scripture, Gospel, Psalms, Quran, Amendment, and Eucharist), as well as concepts related to government, law, and politics.

Nouns or words related to verbs of motion or verbs indicating progression (e.g. "go", "went"), proper nouns (e.g. "Gol", "Gio Gonzalez", "Gough"), or words that are part of a title or a name (e.g. "Goblet", "Golem", "Gospel", "Goals").
References to the Bible, particularly the Gospel of Matthew, often including the book name and chapter number.
